alludo: <entryFree id="n1966" type="main" key="allu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">al-lūdo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>ūsi, ūsum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n1966.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To play</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sport with</hi> any thing, <hi rend="ital">to joke</hi>, <hi rend="ital">jest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to do</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">sportively;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case> (most freq. after the Aug. per.; never in Plaut.; and in Ter. and in Cic. only once), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 1, 34</bibl>: Galba autem adludens (<hi rend="ital">discoursing in jests</hi>) varie et copiose multas similitudines adferre, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:56:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 56, 240</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">occupato,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:864" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 864</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec plura adludens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cicero Trebatio adludens,</quote> <trans><tr>jesting with</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:11:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 11, 18</bibl></cit> Spald., Halm; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:22 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 22 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1966.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the motion, </sense><sense id="n1966.2" n="A" level="2"> Of the waves, <hi rend="ital">to sport with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to play against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dash upon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare terram appetens litoribus adludit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:39:100" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 39, 100</bibl></cit>: solebat Aquilius, quid esset litus, ita definire, quā fluctus adluderet (B. and K. read <hi rend="ital">eluderet;</hi> v. eludo), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:7:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 7, 32</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:14:34" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 14, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adludentibus undis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:342" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 342</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia, quae ... fluctus salis adludebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 66</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1966.3" n="B" level="2"> Of the wind, <hi rend="ital">to play with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">summa cacumina silvae lenibus adludit flabris levis Auster,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:664" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 664</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tremens Adludit patulis arbor hiatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 157" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 157</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alluo: <entryFree id="n1967" type="main" key="allu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">al-lŭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>ŭi, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to flow near to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to wash against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bathe</hi>, of the sea, the waves, etc. (perh. not used before the Cic. per.). </sense><sense id="n1967.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adluuntur a mari moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:37:section=96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 37, § 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita jactantur fluctibus, ut numquam adluantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluvius latera haec adluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flumen quo adluitur oppidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 149</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis ora vicina adluens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 1232" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 1232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adluit gentes Maeotis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Oedip. 475" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oedip. 475</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1967.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: <cit><quote lang="la">(Massilia) cincta Gallorum gentibus barbariae fluctibus adluitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 26, 63</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
allus: <entryFree id="n1968" type="gloss" key="allus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">allus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>: pollex scandens proximum digitum, quod velut insiluisse in alium videtur, quod Graece <foreign lang="greek">a(/llesqai</foreign> dicitur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.; kindr. with allex, q. v.</entryFree>
allusio: <entryFree id="n1969" type="hapax" key="allu_si^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">allūsĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alludo</etym>, <sense id="n1969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a playing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sporting with</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 229</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alluvies: <entryFree id="n1970" type="main" key="allu^vi^es"><orth extent="full" lang="la">allŭvĭes</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>ēi</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alluo</etym>. <sense id="n1970.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A pool of water occasioned by the overflowing of the sea</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a river</hi>: in proximā adluvie pueros exponunt, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1970.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Land formed by overflow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alluvial land</hi>: fluminum adluvie, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:11:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 11, 8</bibl>.—In the <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare quietas adluvies temperabat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 260, 29</bibl></cit> Elm.</sense></entryFree>
alluvio: <entryFree id="n1971" type="main" key="allu^vi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">allŭvĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n1971.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">a washing upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an overflowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an inundation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adluvione paulatim terra consumitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 14, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra aquarum saepe adluvionibus mersa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mund. p. 67, 41</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1971.1" n="II" level="1"> In the jurists, <hi rend="ital">an accession of land gradually washed to the shore by the flowing of water</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alluvial land</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod per adluvionem agro nostro flumen adjecit, jure gentium nobis adquiritur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:1:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 1, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:1:13" default="NO">19, 1, 13</bibl> —Hence, jura adluvionum et circumluvio num, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:38:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 38, 173</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:1:12" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 1, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alluvius: <entryFree id="n1972" type="hapax" key="allu^vi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">allŭvĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adl-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1972.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">al luvial</hi>: ager, Auct. Var. Lim p. 293 Goes. <pb n="95" /> <cb n="ALO" /></sense></entryFree>
almities: <entryFree id="n1973" type="gloss" key="almi^ties"><orth extent="full" lang="la">almĭties</orth> <etym>almus</etym>, <sense id="n1973.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">benignity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kind behavior</hi>: habitus almarum rerum, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 25</bibl> P.: ALMITIES, ALMITIEI: <foreign lang="greek">eu)pe/peia</foreign>.</sense></entryFree>
almo: <entryFree id="n1974" type="main" key="Almo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Almo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small stream</hi>, <hi rend="ital">almost entirely dry in summer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the south side of Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crossing the</hi> Via Appia <hi rend="ital">and</hi> Via Ostiensis, <hi rend="ital">flows into the Tiber</hi> (now the <hi rend="ital">Aquataccia</hi>). In it the priests of Cybele annually washed the image and sacred implements of the temple of that goddess; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:337" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 337</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 340</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:47" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:600" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 600</bibl>; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 588; Müll. Roms Campagn. 2, 400 sq.—As <hi rend="ital">a river-god</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of the nymph Lara</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:601" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 601</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
almus: <entryFree id="n1975" type="main" key="almus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">almus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1975.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affording nourishment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cherishing</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> epithet of Ceres, Venus, and other patron deities of the earth, of light, day, wine, etc.; cf. Bentl. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 4, 13</bibl>).—Hence, <hi rend="ital">genial</hi>, <hi rend="ital">restoring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reviving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">propitious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indulgent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bountiful</hi>, etc.: O Fides alma, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:29:104" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 29, 104</bibl> (Trag. v. 410 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">nutrix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Venus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:15:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 15, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mater terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:992" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 992</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:231 al" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 231 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ceres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Phoebe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 10, 215</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cybele,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 220</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 2, 330</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vites,</quote> <trans><tr>refreshing</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 233</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">Faustitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Maia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Musae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 7, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sol,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,002:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> C. S. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorea, i.e. gloria, quae virtutem nutrit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 4, 4, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pales,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:722" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 722</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacerdos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:9:51" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 9, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubera,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 2, 383 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
alneus: <entryFree id="n1976" type="main" key="alne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alnĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alnus</etym>, <sense id="n1976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">made of alder</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">palus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alnus: <entryFree id="n1977" type="main" key="alnus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>akin to Swed. al; A. S. aler; Germ. Eller; Engl. alder, elder</etym>, <sense id="n1977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the alder</hi>, which flourishes in moist places: Betula alnus, Linn.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 40, 79, § 218</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:17:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 17, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 110</bibl>: alnorum umbracula, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 4</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, any thing <hi rend="ital">made of alder-wood;</hi> so esp., <hi rend="ital">a ship</hi>, since it was much used in ship-building: <cit><quote lang="la">tunc alnos primum fluvii sensere cavatas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 136</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 451</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:2:426" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 2, 426</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amica fretis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:6:106 al" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 6, 106 al.</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and of pales or posts,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:2:486" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 2, 486</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:422" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 422</bibl>.—The sisters of Phaëton, while bewailing his death, were changed to alders, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 62</bibl>; cf. with it <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:190" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 10, 190</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Fescenn. Nupt. Hon. 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alo: <entryFree id="n1978" type="main" key="a^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălo</orth>, <itype>ălŭi, altum, and ălĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (the ante-class. and class. form of the <sense id="n1978.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi> from Plautus until after Livy is altus (in Cic. four times); alitus seems to have been first used in the post-Aug. per. to distinguish it from altus, the <pos>adj.</pos> Altus is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 36</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 237, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:33:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 33, 81</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:10:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 10, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:46:118" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 46, 118</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 63, 3</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">on the contrary, alitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:10:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 10, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:4:4" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:4:7" default="NO">5, 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:4:1" default="NO">7, 4, 1</bibl>; 9, 3, 8; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 3</bibl>, praef. 10; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:44:4:12" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 44, 4, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:27:3:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 27, 3, 1</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 897</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 371</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 220</bibl> P.; Wund. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:page=201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. p. 201</bibl>) [cf.: <foreign lang="greek">a)/n-altos</foreign> = insatiable, <foreign lang="greek">a)/lsos</foreign> = growth (of wood), 1. ad-oleo, ad-olesco, elementum; Goth. alan = to bring up; Germ. alt = old; Engl. old, eld, elder, and alderman], <hi rend="ital">to feed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to nourish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">support</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sustain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">maintain</hi> (in gen. without designating the means, while <hi rend="ital">nutrire</hi> denotes sustenance by animal food; cf. Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 32</bibl>; Doed. Syn. II. p. 99). </sense><sense id="n1978.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem ego nefrendem alui, Liv. And. ap. Fest. s. v. nefrendes, p. 163 Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 5 Rib.): Athenis natus altusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alebat eos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:47:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 47, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">esurientes alebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Tob. 1, 20</bibl></cit>.—With natus, educatus, or a similar word, several times: Alui, educavi, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 422, 14</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 150 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum Hannibale alto atque educato inter arma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 28</bibl></cit> (cf. II. infra): <cit><quote lang="la">aut equos Alere aut canes ad venandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alere nolunt hominem edacem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam cibus auget corpus alitque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:859" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 859</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:221 al" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 221 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae etiam aleret adulescentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">milites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nautas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnum numerum equitatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum agellus eum non satis aleret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:26:72" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 26, 72</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,019:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Phoc. 1, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">locus ille, ubi altus aut doctus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:33:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 33, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus animantes aluntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(animus) aletur et sustentabitur isdem rebus, quibus astra sustentantur et aluntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 19, 43</bibl></cit> <cb n="ALO" /> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">latrociniis se suosque alebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:8:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 8, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos manus aut lingua perjurio aut sanguine civili alebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. Kritz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 37:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 37, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nepotem elephantos alere prohiberet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 9, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">canes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod alerentur regiones eorum ab illo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:12:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 12, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">velut amnis imbres Quem super notas aluere ripas,</quote> <trans><tr>have swollen</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rhombos aequora alebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:48 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 2, 48 al.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:339" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 339</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 411</bibl>; and in a paradoxical phrase: infelix minuendo corpus alebat, <hi rend="ital">and sustained his body by consuming it</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">nourished himself by his own flesh</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:878" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 878</bibl> al.—Hence in <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> with the <case>abl.</case> = vesci, <hi rend="ital">to be nourished</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sustained with</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to live</hi> or <hi rend="ital">feed upon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">panico vetere atque hordeo corrupto omnes alebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia viperinis carnibus alantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 2, 2, § 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">locustis eos ali, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 2, 2, § 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc cibo aliti sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:16:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 16, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1978.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to nourish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cherish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">promote</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strengthen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">honos alit artes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eā ipsā urbe, in quā et nata et alta sit eloquentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:10:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 10, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominis mens alitur discendo et cogitando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec studia adulescentiam alunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 7, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Ochsn. Eclog. 134 al.: civitas, quam ipse semper aluisset,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>whose prosperity he had always promoted</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vires,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nolo meis impensis illorum ali augerique luxuriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,019:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Phoc. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alere morbum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 21 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insita hominibus libido alendi de industriā rumores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regina Vulnus alit venis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiis alitur luxuriosus amor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 746</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alitur diutius controversia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid alat formetque poëtam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:307 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 307 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence, altus, a, um.</sense></entryFree>
aloe: <entryFree id="n1979" type="greek" key="a^lo^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălŏē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<gen>n.</gen> in <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Art. Vet. 1, 14</bibl>. 5; 1, 45, 5), = <foreign lang="greek">a)lo/h</foreign>, <sense id="n1979.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the aloe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 5</bibl>; used as a medicine, Cels 1, 3; 2, 12; <cit><quote lang="la">as a perfume,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 7, 17</bibl></cit>; ib Cant. 4, 14; <cit><quote lang="la">in embalming,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:19:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 19, 39</bibl></cit>.—On accouns of its bitterness, trop.: plus aloës quam mellis habet, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:180" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 180</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aloeus: <entryFree id="n1980" type="main" key="A^lo_eus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălōeus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi and ĕos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alweu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1980.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a giant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Otus and Ephialtes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 28" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:410" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 410</bibl>. <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. G. 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alogia: <entryFree id="n1981" type="greek" key="a^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)logi/a</foreign> <sense id="n1981.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Irration al conduct</hi> or <hi rend="ital">action</hi>, <hi rend="ital">folly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne tibi alogias excutiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Mort. Claud. 7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Mort. Claud. 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1981.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Dumbness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">muteness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 86" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alogus: <entryFree id="n1982" type="greek" key="a^lo^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălŏgus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/logos</foreign>. <sense id="n1982.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">destitute of reason</hi>, <hi rend="ital">irrational</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animalia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 86" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 86</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1982.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1982.2" n="A" level="2"> In math.: <cit><quote lang="la">aloga linea,</quote> <trans><tr>one that does not correspond with another</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1982.3" n="B" level="2"> In verse: <cit><quote lang="la">alogus pes,</quote> <trans><tr>irregular</tr>, <tr>which corresponds with no kind of measure</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> 9, p. 329</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aloidae: <entryFree id="n1983" type="main" key="A^lo_i_dae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălōīdae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alwei=dai</foreign>, <sense id="n1983.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the sons of Aloeus</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Otus and Ephialtes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:582" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 582</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 117</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. G. 73</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alone: <entryFree id="n1984" type="main" key="A^lo_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălōnē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Hal-</orth>), <itype>es</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n1984.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island between Teos and Lebedus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 87, 89, § 202</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1984.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island in the Propontis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:151" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 44, § 151</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1984.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A colony of Massilia in Hisp. Tarrac.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:6:6" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 6, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1984.3" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Britannia</hi>, Itin. Ant.</sense></entryFree>
aloni: <entryFree id="n1985" type="main" key="A^lo_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălōni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1985.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Mesopotamia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30, § 118</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alope: <entryFree id="n1986" type="main" key="A^lo^pe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălŏpē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alo/ph</foreign>. <sense id="n1986.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Daughter of Cercyon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and mother of Hippothoüs by Neptune</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who changed her into a fountain</hi>, Hyg. <cb n="ALPH" /> Fab. 187.—</sense><sense id="n1986.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Locris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 7, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alopecia: <entryFree id="n1987" type="greek" key="a^lo_pe^ci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălōpĕcĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lwpeki/a</foreign>, <sense id="n1987.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the foxsickness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in which the hair falls off</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the foxmange</hi>, a disease common among foxes (usu. in <number>plur.</number>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:239" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 22, 87, § 239</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:41" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 5, 20, § 41</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alopecis: <entryFree id="n1988" type="greek" key="a^lo_pe^cis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălōpĕcis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lwpeki/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1988.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of vine which produces clusters resembling the tail of a fox</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caudas volpium imitata alopecis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 3, 4, § 42</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alopecuros: <entryFree id="n1989" type="greek" key="a^lo_pe^cu_ros"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălōpĕcūros</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lwpe/kouros</foreign> (fox-tail), <sense id="n1989.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of plant</hi>, acc. to Sprengel, Saccharum cylindricum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 17, 61, § 101</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alopex: <entryFree id="n1990" type="greek" key="a^lo_pex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălōpex</orth>, <itype>ĕcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lwpeki/as</foreign>, <sense id="n1990.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of shark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi>, in pure Lat., volpes marina, <hi rend="ital">sea - fox</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thresher - shark</hi>: squalus vulpes, Cuv.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 11, 53, § 145</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">volpes marinae simili in periculo glutiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 43, 67, § 145</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alosa: <entryFree id="n1991" type="main" key="a^lo_sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălōsa</orth>, v. alausa.</entryFree>
alpes: <entryFree id="n1992" type="main" key="Alpes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alpes</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype> (rare in <number>sing.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alpis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">h( *)/alpis</foreign>; cf. Rudd. I. p. 157, n. 78), <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai( *)/alpeis</foreign> [v. albus], <sense id="n1992.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">High mountains;</hi> and <foreign lang="greek">kat) e)coxh/n</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the high mountains of Switzerland</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Alps</hi>, unknown to the Romans, in their whole extent, until the time of Augustus. The three principal ranges, running S.W. and N.E., are, </sense><sense id="n1992.1" n="I" level="1"> The western division between Italy and France. </sense><sense id="n1992.2" n="A" level="2"> Alpes Maritimae, <hi rend="ital">the Maritime Alps</hi>, extending from the sources of the Var, in a S.E. direction, to the sea, between the present Nice and Piedmont. North of these are, </sense><sense id="n1992.3" n="B" level="2"> Alpes Cottiae (so called from Cottius, a prefect in that region under Augustus), <hi rend="ital">the Cottian Alps</hi>, west of Augusta Taurinorum, whose highest peak was Alpis Cottia, now <hi rend="ital">Mont Genevre.</hi> Next to these, on the north. </sense><sense id="n1992.4" n="C" level="2"> Alpes Graiae (Graiae, a Celtic word of uncertain signif., sometimes falsely referred to Hercules Graius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 3, 4</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">the Graian Alps</hi>, extending to Mont Blanc (Alpis Graia is <hi rend="ital">the Little St. Bernard</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n1992.5" n="II" level="1"> East of these, the middle division, as the northern boundary of Italy. </sense><sense id="n1992.6" n="A" level="2"> Alpes Penninae (so called from the deity Penninus, worshipped there; acc. to some, with the orthog. Poeninae, erroneously, with reference to Hannibal), <hi rend="ital">the Pennine</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Vallisian Alps</hi>, between Vallais and Upper Italy, whose highest peak, Mons Penninus, <hi rend="ital">the Great St. Bernard</hi>, seems to have been out little known even in the time of Cæsar; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 1</bibl>.—Connected with these on the N.E. are, </sense><sense id="n1992.7" n="B" level="2"> Alpes Lepontinae, <hi rend="ital">the Lepontine Alps</hi>, the eastern continuation of which are, </sense><sense id="n1992.8" n="C" level="2"> Alpes Rhaeticae, <hi rend="ital">the Rhœtian</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Tyrolese Alps</hi>, extending to the Great Glockner.—</sense><sense id="n1992.9" n="III" level="1"> The eastern division. </sense><sense id="n1992.10" n="A" level="2"> Alpes Noricae, <hi rend="ital">the Noric</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Salzburg Alps.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n1992.11" n="B" level="2"> Alpes Carnicae, <hi rend="ital">the Carnic Alps.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n1992.12" n="C" level="2"> Alpes Juliae (prob. so callea from the Forum Julii, situated near), <hi rend="ital">the Julian Alps</hi>, extending to the Adriatic Sea and Illyria.—Cf. Mann Ital. I. p. 31 sq.; I p. 263; I. p. 271; I. p. 192; I. p. 189; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Germ. p. 546</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpes aëriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:474" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 474</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hibernae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 41</bibl></cit>: gelidae. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 183</bibl>: saevae <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:166 al" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 166 al.</bibl>—In <number>sing.</number>: quot in Alpe ferae. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 150</bibl>: Alpis nubiferae colles. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:688" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 688</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">opposuit natura Alpemque nivemque. Juv 10, 152: emissus ab Alpe,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. Gild. 82</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cons. Stil. 3, 285</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1992.13" n="IV" level="1"> Appel. for <hi rend="ital">any high mountain</hi> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">gemmae Alpes,</quote> <trans><tr>the Alps and Pyrenees</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:833" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 833</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Apol. 5, 593</bibl>; Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 3, 538.—Of Athos, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Apol. 2, 510</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alpha: <entryFree id="n1993" type="greek" key="alpha"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alpha</orth>, <gen>n.</gen> <itype>indecl.</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/lfa</foreign>, <sense id="n1993.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Greek name of the first letter of the alphabet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc discunt ante alpha et beta,</quote> <trans><tr>before their letters</tr>, <tr>before they learn to read</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:209" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 209</bibl></cit>. —Hence, prov., <hi rend="ital">the first in any thing</hi> (as <orth extent="full" lang="la">beta</orth> was <hi rend="ital">the second</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">alpha paenulatorum ... beta togatorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:26" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 26</bibl></cit>; so by character instead of name: Ego sum <foreign lang="greek">*a</foreign> et <foreign lang="greek">*w</foreign>, principium et finis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Apoc. 1, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">21, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">22, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alphabetum: <entryFree id="n1994" type="main" key="alpha^be_tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alphăbētum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/lfa bh=ga</foreign>, <sense id="n1994.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the alphabet</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Haeret. 50</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 125</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alpheias: <entryFree id="n1995" type="hapax" key="Alphe_i^a^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alphēĭăs</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alfhia/s</foreign> (sc. nympha), <sense id="n1995.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the nymph and fountain Arethusa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which unites its waters with the river Alpheus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:487" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 487</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alphesiboea: <entryFree id="n1996" type="hapax" key="Alphe^si^boea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alphĕsĭboea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alfesiboia</foreign>, <sense id="n1996.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">daughter of the Arcadian king Phegeus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and</hi> <cb n="ALTA" /> <hi rend="ital">wife of Alcmœon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who afterwards left her and married Callirrhoē.</hi> When her broth ers slew him on this account, she, from anger at the murder, killed them, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:15:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 15, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alpheus: <entryFree id="n1997" type="main" key="Alphe_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alphēus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>) or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alphēŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alfeio/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1997.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the chief river in the Peloponnesus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Rufia.</hi> It rises in the southern part of Arcadia, not far from Asea, unites with the Eurotas, and then losing itself under ground, makes its appearance again in Megalopolis. It afterwards flows, in a north-west direction, through Arcadia to Elis, and then turns west from Olympia, and falls into the Ionian Sea. At its mouth there was a grove consecrated to Diana or Alphiusa (Mann. Greece, 467 sq. 503). Its disappearance under ground gives occasion for the fable that it flows under the sea, and appearing again in Sicily, mingles with the waters of Arethusa.—Hence personified as <hi rend="ital">the lover of the nymph Arethusa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 250</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 599</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:6:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 6, 29</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 1</bibl> sqq.).—Hence. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alphēus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um. <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alfei=os</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Alpheus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpheae Pisae, founded by a colony from Pisa, in Elis, on the river Alpheus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 179</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpheae ripae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. Get. 575</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alphus: <entryFree id="n1998" type="greek" key="alphus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alphus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lfo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1998.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a white spot upon the skin</hi>, Cels 5, 28, 19; Prisc. de Diaeta, 15.</sense></entryFree>
alpicus: <entryFree id="n1999" type="main" key="Alpi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alpĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Alpes</etym>, a rare form for Alpinus, <sense id="n1999.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Alpine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">PER MONTES ALPICOS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1613</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst. plur.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of the Alpine regions.</hi> Alpicos conantes prohibere transitum concidit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 3, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alpinus: <entryFree id="n2000" type="main" key="Alpi_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alpīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2000.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Alps</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Alpine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rigor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:794" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 794</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nives,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:19:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 19, 47</bibl></cit>: Padus, <hi rend="ital">which rises among the Alps</hi>, Valgius ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 11, 457</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">gentes,</quote> <trans><tr>dwelling upon the Alps</tr>, <tr>Alpine people</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpinus hostis,</quote> <trans><tr>the Gauls who crossed the Alps and invaded Italy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:358" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 358</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpini mures,</quote> <trans><tr>marmots</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 37, 55, § 132</bibl></cit>.—Horace, on account of a bombastic line of the poet M. Furius Bibaculus, in relation to the Alps (Juppiter hibernas canā nive conspuit Alpes), calls him jestingly Alpinus, S. 1, 10, 36; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 5, 41</bibl>; Weich. Poët. Latin. 334 sq.</sense></entryFree>
alpis: <entryFree id="n2001" type="main" key="Alpis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alpis</orth>, v. Alpes.</entryFree>
alsidena: <entryFree id="n2002" type="main" key="alsidena"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alsidena</orth>, <sense id="n2002.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of onion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caepe genera apud Graecos alsidena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 6, 32, § 101</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alsiensis: <entryFree id="n2003" type="main" key="Alsi^ensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alsĭensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>v. 2. Alsius</etym>, <sense id="n2003.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the city of Alsium</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Alsiensi (sc. agro),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 38</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alsine: <entryFree id="n2004" type="greek" key="alsi_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alsīnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lsi/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n2004.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a luxuriant plant</hi>, perh. <hi rend="ital">chickweed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Stellaria nemorum, Linn.: Alsine, quam quidam myosoton appellant, nascitur in lucis, unde et alsine dicta est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 8, § 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alsiosus: <entryFree id="n2005" type="main" key="alsi^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alsĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. alsius</etym>, <sense id="n2005.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">easily freezing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">susceptible to cold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:3:6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: Alsiosa (Habrotonum et Adonium) admodum sunt, Plin 21, 10, 34, § 60.</sense></entryFree>
alsius: <entryFree id="n2006" type="main" key="alsi^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alsĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">alsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>algeo</etym>, <sense id="n2006.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">chilly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cool</hi> (only once in Lucr. and twice in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">alsia corpora,</quote> <trans><tr>cold bodies</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1015" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1015</bibl></cit>.—The form alsus only in the <hi rend="ital">comp. neutr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antio nihil quietius, nihil alsius, nihil amoenius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 8</bibl></cit>: Jam <foreign lang="greek">a)poduthri/w|</foreign> nihil alsius, nihil muscosius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1</bibl>; cf Rudd. I. p. 179, n. 52.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2007" type="main" key="Alsi^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alsĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n2007.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to the maritime city Alsium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Etruria</hi> (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:14" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 14</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Mann. Ital. I. p 380): litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:476" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 476</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tellus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Rutil.</author> Itin. Anton. p. 300</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
altanus: <entryFree id="n2008" type="main" key="alta_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2008.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a south-southwest wind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between the Africus and Libonotus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 6, 10</bibl>, cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 43, 44, § 114</bibl> (acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 13, 11</bibl> and <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 7, 27</bibl>, the sea winds were so called quod ab alto spirant).</sense></entryFree>
altar: <entryFree id="n2009" type="main" key="altar"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altar</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">altāre</orth>, <itype>āris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. altaria.</entryFree>
altaria: <entryFree id="n2010" type="main" key="alta_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altārĭa</orth>, <itype>jum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (ante-class and class. only in <number>plur.</number>; later in <number>sing.</number>, in three forms: <orth extent="full" lang="la">altāre</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, Fest. s. v. adulescit, p. 5; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 15, 4</bibl>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">altar</orth>, <itype>āris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>.; Vincent. 2, 515, and 9, 212; and <orth extent="full" lang="la">altārĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2519</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 69</bibl>.—<sense id="n2010.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Abl.</hi> altari, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 135</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:33:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 33, 20</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:23:20 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 23, 20 al.</bibl>) [cf. adoleo, adolesco, as sacrificial terms, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=5" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 5</bibl> Müll., or altus <pb n="97" /> <cb n="ALTE" /> from its height, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> p. 29; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 5, 66</bibl>]. </sense><sense id="n2010.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That which was placed upon the altar proper</hi> (ara) <hi rend="ital">for the burning of the victim</hi> (altaria sunt, in quibus igne adoletur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=5" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 5</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> p. 29): <cit><quote lang="la">celeres urunt altaria flammae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:6:17" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">structae diris altaribus arae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:404" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 404</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aris altaria imponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 12:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 12, 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 9</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2010.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> (pars pro toto), <hi rend="ital">a high altar</hi> (built and ornamented with more splendor than the ara; cf. Voss ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 66</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Hab. Syn. 129): Conspergunt aras adolentque altaria donis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1237" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1237</bibl></cit>: en quattuor aras; <cit><quote lang="la">Ecce duas tibi, Daphni, duas altaria Phoebo,</quote> <trans><tr>two high altars to Phœbus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 66</bibl></cit> (ubi v. Wagn. and Voss): <cit><quote lang="la">inter aras et altaria, i. e. in Capitolio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:1:5" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altaria thymiamatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:30:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 30, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:11:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 11, 3 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">aedificabit ibi altare Domino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:12:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 12, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:25:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 25, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 5, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">altare de terrā facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:20:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Exod. 20, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altare lapideum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 20, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altare aureum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Num. 4, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:8:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 8, 3 al.</bibl> persaepe.—Also <number>plur.</number> of <hi rend="ital">a single altar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a cujus altaribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab altaribus fugatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoveri ab altaribus juvenem jussisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hannibalem altaribus admotum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altaria et aram complexa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sumptis in manus altaribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:2" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 24, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:94" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 94</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
altarium: <entryFree id="n2011" type="main" key="alta_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altārĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. altaria <sense id="n2011.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
alte: <entryFree id="n2012" type="main" key="alte_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. alo, <sense id="n2012.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
altegradius: <entryFree id="n2013" type="hapax" key="alte_^gra^di^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">altē^grădĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">altī^gr-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = alte gradiens, <sense id="n2013.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">walking erect</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Vel. Virg. 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
altellus: <entryFree id="n2014" type="gloss" key="Altellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Altellus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2014.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname of Romulus</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
alter: <entryFree id="n2015" type="main" key="alter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alter</orth>, <itype>tĕra, tĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (the measure of the <sense id="n2015.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. sing.</hi> āltĕrĭŭs as paeon primus is supported in good Latin only by examples from dactylic verse (but see alterĭus in trochaic measure, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 56</bibl>), in which īpsĭŭs, īllĭŭs, īstĭŭs, ūnĭŭs, etc., are used as dactyls; on the contr., the regular measure āltĕrīŭs, as ditrochaeus, is sufficiently confirmed by the foll. verses of Enn., Ter., and Ter. Maur.: mox cum alterīus abligurias bona, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Donat.</author> ad Ter. Phorm. 2, 2, 25</bibl> (Sat. 29 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">alterīus sua comparent commoda? ah!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec alter[imacracute]us indigéns opís veni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:page=2432" default="NO"><author>Ter. Maur.</author> p. 2432</bibl></cit> P.; <cit><quote lang="la">and sescupló vel una víncet alter[imacracute]us singulum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> p. 2412 ib.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 695</bibl> ib.; alterius is also commonly used as the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> of alius, as alīus is little used (v. h. v. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>).—<hi rend="ital">Dat. sing. f.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alterae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 1, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:11:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 11, 10</bibl>) [a <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi> form of al-ius; cf. Sanscr. antara = alius; Goth. anthar; Lith. antras = secundus; Germ. ander; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e(/teros</foreign>; Engl. either, other; also Sanscr. itara = alius], <hi rend="ital">the other of two</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of two</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the other</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">o( e(/teros</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n2015.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2015.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">nam huic alterae patria quae sit, profecto nescio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">necesse est enim sit alterum de duobus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:41:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 41, 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altera ex duabus legionibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 20</bibl></cit>: mihi cum viris ambobus est amicitia; <cit><quote lang="la">cum altero vero magnus usus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:42:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 42, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alter consulum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alter ex censoribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 40, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in alterā parte fluminis legatum reliquit,</quote> <trans><tr>on the other side</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis te percusserit in dexteram maxillam tuam, praebe illi et alteram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 5, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">28, 1</bibl>.—Hence: alter ambove, <hi rend="ital">one or both;</hi> commonly in the abbreviation: <cit><quote lang="la">A. A. S. E. V. = alter ambove si eis videretur: utique C. Pansa, A. Hirtius consules alter ambove S. E. V. rationem agri habeant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> Wernsd.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 11</bibl>; 9, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 14, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Brison. Form. pp. 218 and 219: absente consulum altero ambobusve,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 23</bibl></cit>: ambo alterve, S. C. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aquaed. 100" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aquaed. 100 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2015.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n2015.4" n="1. a." level="1"> In distributive clauses: alter ... alter, <hi rend="ital">the one ... the other</hi> (cf. alius, II. A.): <foreign lang="greek">o( e(/teros ... o( e(/teros</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">Si duobus praefurniis coques, lacunā nihil opus erit. Cum cinere eruto opus erit, altero praefurnio eruito, in altero ignis erit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 38, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alteram ille amat sororem, ego alteram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:4:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 4, 68</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum alter exercitum perdidit, alter vendidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 35</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 6, 16</bibl>: namque alterā ex parte Bellovaci instabant; <cit><quote lang="la">alteram Camulogenus tenebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 59</bibl></cit> <cb n="ALTE" /> Herz.: <cit><quote lang="la">conjunxit alteram (cortinam) alteri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:36:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 36, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">36, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:13:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 13, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 12, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2015.5" n="b" level="4"> In same sense, unus ... alter, <hi rend="ital">one ... the other</hi>, as in later Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ei(=s me/n ... e(/teros de/</foreign>: vitis insitio una est per ver, altera est cum uva floret; <cit><quote lang="la">ea optima est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 41, 1</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Phorm.</hi> Una injuria est tecum. <hi rend="ital">Chrem.</hi> Lege agito ergo. <hi rend="ital">Phorm.</hi> Altera est tecum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 90</bibl>: uni epistolae respondi; <cit><quote lang="la">venio ad alteram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 17, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen uni Ada, et nomen alteri Sella,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 4, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 6, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Erant duae factiones, quarum una populi causam agebat, altera optimatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,019:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Phoc. 3, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">consules coepere duo creari, ut si unus malus esse voluisset, alter eum coërceret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Duo homines ascenderunt in templum, unus pharisaeus et alter publicanus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:18:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 18, 10 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2015.6" n="c" level="4"> Sometimes a <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">hic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ille</hi>, etc., stands in the place of the second alter: <cit><quote lang="la">Epaminondas ... Leonidas: quorum alter, etc ... Leonidas autem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:30:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 30, 97</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:71:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 71, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alter gladiator habetur, hic autem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum alteri Capitoni cognomen est, iste, qui adest, magnus vocatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alterum corporis aegritudo, illum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:7" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 7</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes </sense><sense id="n2015.7" n="(a)" level="5"> one alter is entirely omitted (cf. alius, II. A.; <foreign lang="greek">e(/teros</foreign>, L. and S. I. 2.): <cit><quote lang="la">duae turmae haesere: altera metu dedita hosti, pertinacior (sc. altera), etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hujus lateris alter angulus ad orientem solem, inferior ad meridiem spectat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 13</bibl></cit>; or </sense><sense id="n2015.8" n="(b)" level="5"> the form changed: <cit><quote lang="la">dialecticam adjungunt et physicam, alteram quod habeat rationem .... Physicae quoque etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:21:72" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 21, 72</bibl></cit>, and 3, 22, 73. —Sometimes a further distributive word is added: <cit><quote lang="la">alter adulescens decessit, alter senex, aliquis praeter hos infans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 66:39" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 66, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alter in vincula ducitur, alter insperatae praeficitur potestati, alius etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2015.9" n="d" level="4"> In <number>plur.</number>: nec ad vivos pertineat, nec ad mortuos; <cit><quote lang="la">alteri nulli sunt, alteros non attinget,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:38:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 38, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alteri dimicant, alteri victorem timent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 3</bibl></cit>: binas a te accepi litteras; quarum alteris mihi gratulabare ... alteris dicebas etc., <hi rend="ital">in one of which</hi>, ... <hi rend="ital">in the other</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum alteri adjuvabant, alteri etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 17</bibl></cit>: duplices similitudines, unae rerum, alterae verborum, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 20</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2015.10" n="e" level="4"> The second alter in a different case: <cit><quote lang="la">alter alterius ova frangit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uterque numerus plenus, alter alterā de causā habetur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui noxii ambo, alter in alterum causam conferant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alteri alteros aliquantum attriverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 79:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 79, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 42:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 42, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">53, 7 al. —Also with alteruter: ne alteruter alterum praeoccuparet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 4, 1</bibl></cit>.—With unus: <cit><quote lang="la">quom inter nos sorderemus unus alteri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 4, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicunt unus ad alterum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ez. 33, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne unus adversus alterum infletur pro alio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Cor. 4, 6</bibl></cit>.—With uterque: <cit><quote lang="la">uterque suo studio delectatus contempsit alterum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:1:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrique alteris freti finitimos sub imperium suum coëgere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 18:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 18, 12</bibl></cit>.—With nemo, nullus, neuter: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nemo sit alteri similis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:9:2" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 9, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tot saeculis nulla referta sit causa, quae esset tota alteri similis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7</bibl></cit>, prooem. 4: <cit><quote lang="la">neutrum eorum contra alterum juvare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut neutra alteri officiat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:1:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—After two <hi rend="ital">substt.</hi>, the first alter generally refers to the first subst., and the second to the second: <cit><quote lang="la">Philippum rebus gestis superatum a filio, facilitate video superiorem fuisse. Itaque alter semper magnus, alter saepe turpissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 26</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 21</bibl>; Brem. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 20</bibl>.—Sometimes the order is reversed: contra nos (summa gratia et eloquentia) raciunt in hoc tempore; <cit><quote lang="la">quarum alteram (i. e. eloquentiam) vereor, alteram (i. e. gratiam) metuo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 12</bibl>; cf. Spald. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 2, 6</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2015.11" n="2" level="3"> As a numeral = secundus, <hi rend="ital">the second</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the next</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">o/ e(/teros</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">primo die, alter dies, tertius dies, deinde reliquis diebus etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proximo, altero, tertio, reliquis consecutis diebus non intermittebas etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 13</bibl></cit> Wernsd.: <cit><quote lang="la">quadriennio post alterum consulatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">die altero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,006:10:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jos. 10, 32</bibl></cit>: alteris Te mensis adhibet deum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">at the dessert</hi> (= mensā secundā), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 31</bibl>.—So, alterā die, <hi rend="ital">the next day</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">th=| a)/llh| h(me/ra|, th=| e(te/ra|</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">se alterā die ad conloquium venturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 19</bibl></cit>; <cb n="ALTE" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:19:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 19, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:27:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 27, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">die altero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:11:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Num. 11, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,006:5:11 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jos. 5, 11 al.</bibl>—So in comparative sense: <cit><quote lang="la">alterā die quam a Brindisio solvit, in Macedoniam trajecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">intermittere diem alterum quemque oportet,</quote> <trans><tr>every other day</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Olea non continuis annis, sed fere altero quoque fructum adfert,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 5:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R.
