Fam. 6, 12</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">gloriandi genus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:22" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">preces,</quote> <trans><tr>urgent</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sententiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 8</bibl></cit>: mors, <hi rend="ital">ambitious</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to obtain fame</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicina ars,</quote> <trans><tr>boastful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 1, 8, § 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et quaesitorum pelago terrāque ciborum Ambitiosa fames,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:376" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 376</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atria,</quote> <trans><tr>splendid</tr>, <tr>gorgeous</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:69" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitiosis utilia praeferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitiosius id existimans quam domi suae majestas postularet,</quote> <trans><tr>more condescending</tr>, <tr>submissive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2166.5" n="D" level="2"> In rhet.: orator ambitiosus, <hi rend="ital">who seeks to rouse attention by obsolete</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unusual expressions</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">antigerio nemo nisi ambitiosus utetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 26</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ambĭtĭōsē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">ambitiously</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ostentatiously</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">de triumpho ambitiose agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitiose regnum petere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 35</bibl></cit>: amicitias ambitiose colere, Tac. <pb n="103" /> <cb n="AMBO" /> H. 1, 10 al.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 7</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:68" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambitor: <entryFree id="n2167" type="main" key="ambi_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambītor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ambio</etym>. <sense id="n2167.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a candidate</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2167.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternae laudis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 13, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambitudo: <entryFree id="n2168" type="main" key="ambi^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambĭtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>2. ambitus</etym>, <sense id="n2168.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">period of revolution</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">reditūs,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Trism. 31, p. 258</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambitui: <entryFree id="n2169" type="main" key="Ambitu^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambitŭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2169.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in Galatia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 42, § 146</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambitus: <entryFree id="n2170" type="main" key="ambi_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of ambio.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2171" type="main" key="ambi^tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambĭtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ambio</etym>. <sense id="n2171.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> <hi rend="ital">A going round</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a moving round about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a revolution</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum se octo ambitus ad idem caput rettulerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquae per amoenos ambitus agros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 17</bibl></cit> (cf. ambio, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">alligata mutuo ambitu (i. e. amplexu) corpora,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitu breviore luna currit quam sol,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 23, 21, § 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saeculorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verborum (i. e. ambages),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 71</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2171.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2171.2" n="A" level="2"> Abstr. pro concr., <hi rend="ital">a circuit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">circle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">circumference</hi>, <hi rend="ital">periphery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">edge</hi> of a circular object: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitus parmae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">folia ambitu serrato,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 6, 30, § 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra lato ambitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitus lacus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of discourse, <hi rend="ital">periphrasis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">circumlocution</hi>, = ambages: <cit><quote lang="la">multos circa unam rem ambitus facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 27</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">the open space left round a house</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitus est quod circumeundo teritur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=22" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 22</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">P. Scaevola id solum esse ambitus aedium dixerit, quo etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 4</bibl></cit>: ambitus proprie dicitur inter vicinorum aedificia locus duorum pedum et semipedis ad circumeundi facultatem relictus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=16" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 16</bibl> Müll. —Also, <hi rend="ital">the small space around sepulchres</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:12:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 47, 12, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2171.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An unlawful striving for posts of honor</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">canvassing for office;</hi> esp. by bribery (cf. ambitio, I.), prohibited by the Lex Calpurnia, Caecilia, Fabia, Julia, Licinia, Tullia de ambitu, <hi rend="ital">against bribery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">corruption</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">legem ambitus flagitāsti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">punire ambitum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 32, 67</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 18, 2</bibl> Kritz: <cit><quote lang="la">accusare aliquem ambitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deferre nomen alicujus de ambitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">interrogare aliquem legibus ambitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 18, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">damnatus ambitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condemnare de ambitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:41 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 41 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">effusae ambitus largitiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2171.4" n="C" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">the desire to make a display</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ostentation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vanity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">show</hi>, <hi rend="ital">parade</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">relinque ambitum: tumida res est vana, ventosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 84" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proprius quidam intellegendi ambitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 3</bibl></cit>.—Of speech, <hi rend="ital">bombastic fulness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">parade</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">imagine et ambitu rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 16</bibl></cit> Fr.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Decl. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>— </sense><sense id="n2171.5" n="D" level="2"> In rhet., <hi rend="ital">a period</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">comprehensio et ambitus ille verborum (si sic periodum appellari placet),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:44:162" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 44, 162</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 12</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 50</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambivareti: <entryFree id="n2172" type="main" key="Ambi^vare_ti"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambĭvarēti</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ambĭlarēti</orth>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Am-blŭarēti</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2172.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of</hi> Gallia Celtica, <hi rend="ital">in the neighborhood of the Ambarri</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 75</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 90</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambivariti: <entryFree id="n2173" type="main" key="Ambi^vari_ti"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambĭvarīti</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2173.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of</hi> Gallia Belgica, <hi rend="ital">near the Meuse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the region of the present Breda</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambivium: <entryFree id="n2174" type="hapax" key="ambi^vi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambĭ-vĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>via</etym>, <sense id="n2174.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a double way</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a place where two roads meet</hi>: hic in ambivio navem conscendimus palustrem, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 451, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambivius: <entryFree id="n2175" type="main" key="Ambi^vi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambĭvĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, L. Turpio. <sense id="n2175.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A very distinguished actor in the time of Terence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in most of whose pieces he acted</hi>, v. Didascal. Fab. And., Eun., Heaut., Hec., and Phorm.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:30" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 1:25" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 1, 25</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2175.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambĭvĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a keeper of a restaurant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:59:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 59, 163</bibl>; perh. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:4:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 4, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambo: <entryFree id="n2176" type="main" key="ambo_^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambō^</orth>, <itype>bae, bo</itype>, <sense id="n2176.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">num.</hi> (<hi rend="ital">nom. plur.</hi> ambo for ambae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 1, 7</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi> orig. ambo, analog. to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/mfw</foreign>, but from the adj. use of the word ambos arose; <case>acc.</case> ambo is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 67</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 3, 121</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 5, 3, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:1:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 2, 1, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 4, 8, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 2, 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 2, 140</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 5, 7</bibl>; Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 96</bibl> P.; Cic. (who never uses ambos) Fam. 5, 8; 9, 13; Caes. (who never uses ambos) B. C. 1, 48; Verg. (who never uses ambos) E. 6, 18; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 88</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> A. 12, 342</bibl>; Hor. (who never uses ambos) S. 2, 3, 180; 2, 7, 62; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:7" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 7</bibl>; 26, 26; 27, 27; 30, 14; 35, 22; 38, 53; 40, 46; 41, 18; 45, 19; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:40" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 40</bibl>; Sil. <cb n="AMBR" /> 4, 175; 17, 427 al.; ambos is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0404,001:Com. Rel. p. 194" default="NO"><author>Afran.</author> Com. Rel. p. 194</bibl> Rib. <hi rend="ital">bis;</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 21</bibl>; Ter. (who never uses ambo) Eun. 5, 8, 39; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 2, 42</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 9, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:13:18" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 13, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 10, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:34:10" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 34, 10</bibl>; Sall. (who never uses ambo) J. 21, 4; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Fragm. 4:19:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fragm. 4, 19, 5</bibl> Kritz; Ov. (who never uses ambo) H. 10, 51; Tac. (who never uses ambo) A. 13, 54; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Tob. 3, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eph. 2, 16</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 95</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 744</bibl> P.; Rudd. I. p. 57; Kühn. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:46:110" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 46, 110</bibl>; Neue, Formenl. II. p. 145 sqq.) [<foreign lang="greek">a)/mfw, a)mfo/teroi</foreign>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=4" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 4</bibl> Müll.; kindr. with Sanscr. ubhāu, dual <case>nom.</case> = ambo; Zend. uba; Slav. oba; Lith. abù; Goth. bai, bajōths; Germ. beide; Engl. both], <hi rend="ital">both</hi> (of two objects whose duality is assumed as already known; when not already known, they are designated by <hi rend="ital">duo.</hi> The difference between <hi rend="ital">ambo</hi> and <hi rend="ital">uterque</hi> is thus given by <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 49</bibl> P.: Ambo non est dicendum, nisi de his, qui uno tempore quid faciunt, utpote reges Eteocles et Polynices ambo perierunt quasi unā; Romulus autem et Africanus non ambo triumphārunt, sed uterque; quia diverso tempore). </sense><sense id="n2176.1" n="I" level="1"> Of objects naturally in pairs, as the parts of the body, <hi rend="ital">both</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">manusque ambas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:496" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 496</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">10, 868</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambas palmas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 425</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">10, 844: tinnient ambae aures ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 3, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:21:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 4 Reg. 21, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">circum unum ambove genua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 6, 17, § 59</bibl></cit> (but even here we find duo: <cit><quote lang="la">sumes duos renes (vituli) et adipem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:29:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 29, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">29, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">duas manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 18, 8</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">bis;</hi> 18, 9: <cit><quote lang="la">duae palmae manuum ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Reg. 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duorum luminum,</quote> <trans><tr>of both eyes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:16:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jud. 16, 28</bibl></cit>; so Shaksp., her two eyes, Love's Lab. Lost, iv. 3; <cit><quote lang="la">Haml. i. 4).—So of other things: Tristior illā Terra sub ambobus non jacet ulla polis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:7:64" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 7, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atridas Priamumque, et saevum ambobus Achillen,</quote> <trans><tr>angry with both parties</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:1:458" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 458</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2176.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen., of two objects and no more, <hi rend="ital">the two</hi>, <hi rend="ital">both</hi>: QVOM. PERORANT. AMBO. PRAESENTES. (i.e. actor et reus), Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:2:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 2, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">consules, alter ambove, si eis videretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:19:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5, 19, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambo accusandi estis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam hisce ambo, et servos et era, frustra sunt duo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:3:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 3, 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">erroris ambo complebo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">emit hosce ambos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. prol. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut eos ambos fallam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Tob. 3, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic, qui utrumque probat, ambobus debuit uti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:7:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 7, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">una salus ambobus erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:710" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 710</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plebiscitis cautum, ne quis duos magistratus uno anno gereret, utique liceret consules ambos plebeios creari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar atque Pompeius diversa sibi ambo consilia capiunt ... eodemque die uterque eorum ex castris exercitum educunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amborum verba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civitate Romanā ambos donavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambo occisi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">errant autem ambo senes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:18:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 18, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:15:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 15, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">applicuit ambos ad eum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:48:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gen. 48, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eph. 2, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2176.3" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> = duo: <cit><quote lang="la">partīs ubi se via findit in ambas,</quote> <trans><tr>into two</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:540" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 540</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambracia: <entryFree id="n2177" type="main" key="Ambra^ci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrăcĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ambraki/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2177.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in the south of Epirus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">upon the gulf of the same name</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Arta</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 1, § 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ep. ad Brut. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 4</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2177.1" n="II. A." level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrăcĭ-ensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Ambracian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 43</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Subst. plur.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ambracia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 43</bibl>.—† </sense><sense id="n2177.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrăcĭōtēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ambrakiw/ths</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Ambracian;</hi> hence, vinum ... Ambraciotes (v. abrotonites), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 7, 9, § 76</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2177.3" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrăcĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Ambracian</hi> (more freq. than Ambraciensis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 1, § 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sinus Ambracius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3</bibl>, in which Octavius conquered Antony and Cleopatra in a naval engagement: Ambraciae frondes, i.e. <hi rend="ital">the laurel crown of the victors in the Actian games</hi> (v. Actium and Actiacus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambrices: <entryFree id="n2178" type="gloss" key="ambri^ces"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambrĭces</orth>: regulae, quae transversae asseribus et tegulis interponuntur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=16" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 16</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
ambrosia: <entryFree id="n2179" type="greek" key="ambro^si^a1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambrŏsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mbrosi/a</foreign>. <sense id="n2179.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">ambrosia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the food of the gods</hi> (as nectar was their drink): <cit><quote lang="la">non enim ambrosiā deos aut nectare laetari arbitror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:26:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 26, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:10:11" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 10, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Suaviolum dulci dulcius ambrosiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:99:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 99, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence: orator ambrosiā alendus, prov. once in Cic., qs. <hi rend="ital">a</hi> <cb n="AMBU" /> <hi rend="ital">god among orators</hi>, of a distinguished orator (opp. faenum esse), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 57</bibl>.— Also <hi rend="ital">food for the steeds of the gods</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equos ambrosiae suco saturos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 120</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 215</bibl> (acc. to Hom. Il. 5, 368 and 369).—</sense><sense id="n2179.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2179.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The unguent of the gods</hi> (so, <foreign lang="greek">a)mbrosi/a</foreign>, Hom. Il. 14, 170; <cit><quote lang="la">16, 670): ambrosiā cum dulci nectare mixtā Contigit os,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:606" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 606</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liquidum ambrosiae diffundit odorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:415" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 415</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:419" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 12, 419</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2179.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several plants</hi>, esp. of the botrys or artemisia, <hi rend="ital">Turkish mugwort</hi>: Choenopodium botrys, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 11, § 28</bibl>.—Another plant of this name, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 8, 31, § 55</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2179.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An antidote to poison</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n2180" type="main" key="Ambro^si^a2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrŏsĭa</orth>, v. Ambrosie.</entryFree>
ambrosiacus: <entryFree id="n2181" type="hapax" key="ambro^si^a^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambrŏsĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ambrosia</etym>, <sense id="n2181.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ambrosial</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambrosiaca vitis, on account of the sweetness of its grapes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 3, 4, § 40</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambrosie: <entryFree id="n2182" type="main" key="Ambro^sie_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrŏsiē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-a</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ambrosi/h</foreign>, <sense id="n2182.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Ambrosia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Attas and Pleione</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of the Hyades</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 182" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 182</bibl> and 192; id. poët. Astr. 2, 21.</sense></entryFree>
ambrosius: <entryFree id="n2183" type="greek" key="ambro^si^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambrŏsĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mbro/sios</foreign>, <sense id="n2183.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">immortal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">divine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ambrosial</hi> (syn.: immortalis, divinus), in gen., all that pertains to the gods, and their prerogatives and endowments; hence, an epithet for every thing <hi rend="ital">lovely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pleasant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sweet</hi>, etc. (in gen. only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">comae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:403" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 403</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:731" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 731</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dapes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:39" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:210" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 210</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:408" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 408</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sinus, Claud. Nupt. Hon. et Mar. 110: corpus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 205, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11</bibl></cit>, p. 258, 39: <cit><quote lang="la">color,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10</bibl></cit>, p. 254, 4: <cit><quote lang="la">nectar,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Symm. 1, 276</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2184" type="main" key="Ambro^si^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrŏsĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2184.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a celebrated Church father of the fourth century</hi>, <hi rend="ital">archbishop of Milan.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ambrysus: <entryFree id="n2185" type="main" key="Ambry_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambrȳsus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ambryssos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/ambrusos</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">*)/ambrussos</foreign>, <sense id="n2185.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small town in Phocis</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Dhistomo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 3, 4, § 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambubaia: <entryFree id="n2186" type="main" key="ambu_ba_i^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambūbāĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, usu. in the <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">am-būbāĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>from Syr. <foreign />, <number>plur.</number> <foreign /> = tibia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 14, 7</bibl></etym>, <sense id="n2186.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a class of Syrian girls in Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who supported themselves by their music and immorality</hi>: ambubajarum collegia, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambubajarum ministeria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:27" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 27</bibl></cit>.—In <number>sing.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 74, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambubeia: <entryFree id="n2187" type="main" key="ambube_i^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambubēĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2187.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wild succory</hi> or <hi rend="ital">endive</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 8, 29, § 73</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:8:29:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 8, 29, 1</bibl> ind. 20, 30, p. 68 Sillig.</sense></entryFree>
ambulacrum: <entryFree id="n2188" type="main" key="ambu^la_crum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlācrum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>ambulo</etym>, <sense id="n2188.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a walk planted with trees</hi>, commonly near a house (only ante-and post-class. for the class. ambulatio), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=18" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">senex Gynaeceum aedificare volt hic in suis Et balineas et ambulacrum et porticum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 69</bibl></cit>: longa et mollia ambulacra, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:2:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 18, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatilis: <entryFree id="n2189" type="hapax" key="ambu^la_ti^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2189.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">walking about;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">movable</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatio: <entryFree id="n2190" type="main" key="ambu^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2190.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a walking about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a walk</hi> (only in prose, oftenest in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n2190.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulationem pomeridianam conficere in Academiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">compitaliciae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventum est in ambulationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">recta, flexuosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 2</bibl></cit>.—Of the orator on the platform: <cit><quote lang="la">conveniet etiam ambulatio quaedam propter immodicas laudationum moras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:126" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 126</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2190.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, concr., <hi rend="ital">a walk</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a place for walking</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a promenade</hi> (usu. near a dwelling; either covered or open): ambulatio sub dio pedes lata denos. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5, 9</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:6:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 12, 18, § 83</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatiuncula: <entryFree id="n2191" type="main" key="ambu^la_ti^uncu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātĭuncŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n2191.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dim. f.</hi> [ambulatio], <hi rend="ital">a short walk</hi> (perh. only in the foll. passages of Cic.). </sense><sense id="n2191.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 12</bibl>. —And, </sense><sense id="n2191.2" n="II" level="1"> Concr., <hi rend="ital">a small place for walking</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tecta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulator: <entryFree id="n2192" type="main" key="ambu^la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ambulo</etym>, <sense id="n2192.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that walks about</hi>, i.e., </sense><sense id="n2192.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An idler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lounger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vilicus ne sit ambulator,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 5, 2</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2</bibl>: minus licebit ambulare); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:8:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 8, 7</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n2192.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A pedlar</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hawker</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Transtiberinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:42" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 42</bibl></cit> (not found elsewhere).</sense></entryFree>
ambulatorius: <entryFree id="n2193" type="main" key="ambu^la_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ambulator</etym>, <sense id="n2193.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that moves about</hi> (rare; never in Cic.); hence, </sense><sense id="n2193.1" n="I" level="1"> Of machines which can be moved to and fro. <hi rend="ital">movable</hi>: praeterea alias (so. turres) ambulatorias totidem tabulatorum <pb n="104" /> <cb n="AMBU" /> confixerant, <hi rend="ital">movable towers with an equal number of stories</hi>, Auct. B. Alex. 2 Moeb.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 14, 47, § 80</bibl>.—Hence, trop., of the will, <hi rend="ital">wavering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fickle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">changeable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:1:32" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 24, 1, 32</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and of other things: actio,</quote> <trans><tr>a cause that passes from one to another</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 6, 2, 22</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n2193.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Suitable for walking in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">porticus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:8:5:8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 8, 5, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatrix: <entryFree id="n2194" type="hapax" key="ambu^la_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ambulator</etym>, <sense id="n2194.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that walks about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female lounger</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">vilica ne ambulatrix siet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 143, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatura: <entryFree id="n2195" type="main" key="ambu^la_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ambulo</etym>, <sense id="n2195.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a walking</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a pace</hi>, <hi rend="ital">step</hi>, <hi rend="ital">amble;</hi> only of horses (Fr. <hi rend="ital">l'amble;</hi> Ital. <hi rend="ital">ambio</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ambiadura</hi>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 6, 6, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 6, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 5, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulatus: <entryFree id="n2196" type="hapax" key="ambu^la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2196.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">walking</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Christus scitur ambulatum dedisse contractis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>power to walk</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, p. 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambulo: <entryFree id="n2197" type="main" key="ambu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambŭlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>regarded by Doed. as a sort of dim. of ambio, but better regarded as comp. of am- and the root of <foreign lang="greek">bai/nw</foreign>, beto, -bito, baculum = <foreign lang="greek">ba/kpron</foreign>, vado, venio; Sanscr. gā = go; Germ. gehen; Engl. go. Curtius</etym>. <sense id="n2197.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2197.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to go about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to walk</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum illā neque cubat neque ambulat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:8:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 8, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si non ubi sedeas locus est, est ubi ambules,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. prol. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem ad modum quis ambulet, sedeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:17:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 17, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sedetur, ambulatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:1, p. 72" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, 1, p. 72</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 113:15" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 113, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sedeatur, ambuletur, discumbatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">standi ambulandi vices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:44" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulans aut jacens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:9:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 9, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ambulantis Tiberii genua advolveretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 13</bibl></cit>: aves aliquae ambulant, ut cornices; <cit><quote lang="la">aliae saliunt, ut passeres,</quote> <trans><tr>walk</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 38, 54, § 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegyptii mures bipedes ambulant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 64, 85, § 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">claudi ambulant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 11, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 1, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 20</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2197.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">to walk for recreation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take a walk</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abiit ambulatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">visus sum mihi cum Galbā ambulare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 16, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum in sole ambulem, etiamsi aliam ob causam ambulem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:14:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 14, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus ambulare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To go</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to travel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to journey</hi> (class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. prol. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo ambulas tu?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 185</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">biduo aut triduo septingenta milia passuum ambulare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eo modo Caesar ambulat, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 14</bibl></cit> et saep.—Hence, in the comic poets, bene ambula, <hi rend="ital">farewell</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a good journey to you</hi>, a form oft. used at the departure of any one: <cit><quote lang="la">bene ambula et redambula,</quote> <trans><tr>farewell and farewell back</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 120</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Ty.</hi> Bene ambulato. <hi rend="ital">Ph.</hi> Bene vale, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 92</bibl>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambula,</quote> <trans><tr>go</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 139</bibl></cit>: ambulare in jus, <hi rend="ital">to go into court</hi>, <hi rend="ital">go to law</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambula in jus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 5, 2, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 43</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.4" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To walk about with a certain gravity</hi> or <hi rend="ital">importance</hi>: licet superbus ambules pecuniā. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:4:5" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 2, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 4, 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.5" n="E" level="2"> Of inanimate things: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis, quā naves ambulant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nilus immenso longitudinis spatio ambulans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 10, § 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">velut intus ambulantem (lucem),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 9, 47, § 131</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg> (only post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">quod deinde caput translatum per omnes leges ambulavit,</quote> <trans><tr>was afterwards added to all laws</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 50, 71, § 139</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:4:15" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 4, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulat cum domino bonorum possessio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:11:2" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 37, 11, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.6" n="F" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, esp. with cognate objects, as iter, via, etc., <hi rend="ital">to navigate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sail</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pass over</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Xerxes tantis classibus tantisque copiis maria ambulavisset terramque navigāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perpetuas ambulat illa vias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:122" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 122</bibl></cit> (cf.: ire iter, viam, etc., Burm. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:19:50" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 19, 50</bibl>).— <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si bina stadia ambulentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 1, 16, § 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.7" n="G" level="1"> In milit. lang. t. t., <hi rend="ital">to march</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ter in mense tam equites quam pedites educantur ambulatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 1, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.8" n="H" level="1"> In the jurists in opp. to ire: <cit><quote lang="la">iter est jus eundi ambulandi hominis,</quote> <trans><tr>of one going and coming</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:8:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 3, 8, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2197.9" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> very freq. in eccl. Lat. (like Heb. <foreign /> and N. T. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">peripate/w</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">to walk</hi>, in the sense of <hi rend="ital">to live</hi>, with an adjunct of manner or circumstances: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulavit Henoch cum Deo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 5, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ambules in viis ejus (Dei),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 10, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui ambulant in lege Domini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:118:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 118, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in circuitu impii ambulant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 11, 9</bibl></cit>: fraudulenter ambulare,<cb n="AMEN" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:11:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Prov. 11, 13</bibl>.—So also very freq. in N. T., but only once in this sense in the Gospels: <cit><quote lang="la">quare discipuli tui non ambulant juxta traditionem seniorum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui non secundum carnem ambulant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in carne ambulantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">honeste ambulare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:13:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 13, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ambuletis digne Deo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Col. 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non recte ambularent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,009:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gal. 2, 14</bibl></cit> et persaepe.</sense></entryFree>
amburbale: <entryFree id="n2198" type="main" key="amburba_le"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amburbāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. sacrificium), i. q. amburbium, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 3, 77</bibl>; cf. the two foll. articles.</entryFree>
amburbiales: <entryFree id="n2199" type="gloss" key="amburbi^a_les"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amburbĭāles</orth> <itype>hostiae</itype>, <sense id="n2199.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the victims which were led round the city of Rome</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=5" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 5</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
amburbium: <entryFree id="n2200" type="main" key="amburbi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amb-urbĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>urbs</etym>, <sense id="n2200.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the expiatory procession round the city of Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at which sacrifices were offered</hi> (v. the preced.); <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 3, 77</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=17" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 17</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">lustrata urbs, cantata carmina, amburbium celebratum, ambarvalia promissa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Aur. 20</bibl></cit> (described in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:592 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 592 sq.</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
amburo: <entryFree id="n2201" type="main" key="ambu_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amb-ūro</orth>, <itype>ussi, ustum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n2201.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to burn around</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to scorch</hi> (opp. exurere, to burn entirely up); also, with an extension of the idea, <hi rend="ital">to burn wholly up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consume</hi> (most freq. in <hi rend="ital">part. perf.;</hi> class.). </sense><sense id="n2201.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2201.2" n="A" level="2"> Hadrianus vivus exustus est: <cit><quote lang="la">Verres sociorum ambustus incendio, tamen ex illā flammā periculoque evasit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Herculis corpus ambustum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:68:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 68, 143</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terret ambustus Phaëthon avaras spes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:11:25 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 11, 25 al.</bibl></cit>—So Cicero jestingly calls the tribune of the people Munacius Plancus, at whose suggestion the enraged populace set fire to the senate-house, tribunus ambustus, <hi rend="ital">the singed tribune of the people</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 5, 12</bibl> Moeb.—Of those whom the lightning had struck, but not killed: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 537" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 537</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot circa me jactis fulminibus quasi ambustus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 11, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cassius, quem fama est esse libris Ambustum propriis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna vis frumenti ambusta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambustum theatrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ambu-stum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, in medic. lang., <hi rend="ital">a burn</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inflammatio recentis ambusti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 8, 35, § 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sedare ambusta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 4, 5, § 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambusta sanare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 20, 82, § 217</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambusta igne vel frigore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:45 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 8, 29, § 45 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2201.3" n="B" level="2"> From the similarity of effect, <hi rend="ital">to injure by cold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to nip</hi>, <hi rend="ital">benumb</hi> (cf. aduro): <cit><quote lang="la">ambusti multorum artus vi frigoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambusta pruinis lumina, i. e. oculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:70" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 70</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2201.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2201.5" n="A" level="2"> Of property: <cit><quote lang="la">ambustas fortunarum mearum reliquias,</quote> <trans><tr>the charred remains</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 43</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2201.6" n="B" level="2"> Of one who, when tried for an offence, comes off with great trouble: <cit><quote lang="la">qui damnatione collegae et suā prope ambustus evaserat,</quote> <trans><tr>had come off scorched</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 35</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambustio: <entryFree id="n2202" type="hapax" key="ambusti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambustĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>amburo</etym> = ambustum, <sense id="n2202.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a burn</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">eruptionibus, ambustionibus (medetur myrteum oleum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 4, 44, § 87</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ambustulatus: <entryFree id="n2203" type="hapax" key="ambustu^la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ambustŭlātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2203.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">burned</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scorched around</hi>, <hi rend="ital">roasted</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Teque ambustulatum obiciam magnis avibus pabulum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 65</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ameci: <entryFree id="n2204" type="gloss" key="a^me_ci"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămēci</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămēcae</orth> (a different orthography for amici and amicae), Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=15" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 15</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
amelas: <entryFree id="n2205" type="main" key="Amelas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Amelas</orth>, <sense id="n2205.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Lycia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 27, 28, § 101</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amellus: <entryFree id="n2206" type="main" key="amellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amellus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2206.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the purple Italian starwort</hi>: Aster amellus, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:271" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 271</bibl> (cf. Serv. ad h. 1.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:4:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 4, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amen: <entryFree id="n2207" type="main" key="a_me_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmēn</orth> <etym><foreign />; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)mh/n</foreign></etym> (eccl. Lat.). <sense id="n2207.0" n="I" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">true</hi>, <hi rend="ital">faithful</hi>: (tu Deus) fecisti mirabilia, cogitationes fideles, amen (Heb. <foreign /> = verity), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 25, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2207.1" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">truth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">faith fulness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui benedictus est, benedicetur in Deo amen,</quote> <trans><tr>in the God of faithfulness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:65:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 65, 16</bibl></cit>: haec dicit Amen (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o( *amh/n</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">He that is True</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 3, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2207.2" n="III" level="1"> Most freq. <pos>adv.</pos> </sense><sense id="n2207.3" n="A" level="2"> Prop., to confirm words spoken by one's self or another, <hi rend="ital">So be it;</hi> Fr. <hi rend="ital">Ainsi soit-il;</hi> LXX. <foreign lang="greek">ge/noito</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Amen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et respondebit omnis populus, Amen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:27:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 27, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 22</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Gratia vobiscum, Amen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Tim. 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui (Deo) honor et gloria in saecula saeculorum, Amen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:16:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 16, 27</bibl></cit> et saep. —</sense><sense id="n2207.4" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">truly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">surely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">verily;</hi> very freq. in the phrase. Amen dico vobis, Vulg. <cb n="AMER" /> Matt. 5, 18 al.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:3:28 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 3, 28 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:4:24 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 4, 24 al.</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in St. John: Amen, amen dico vobis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:1:51 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 1, 51 al.</bibl></cit> (The <hi rend="ital">a</hi> is long in Aus. Eph. ap. Orat. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 4, 72</bibl>, but short in Paul. Nol. Poëm. 17 ad Nicet. 117.)</sense></entryFree>
amenanus: <entryFree id="n2208" type="main" key="A^me^na_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕnānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ame/nanos</foreign>, <sense id="n2208.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the southern declivity of Ætna</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 279</bibl>.—Also <pos>adj.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕnānus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um: <cit><quote lang="la">Amenana flumina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:467" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 467</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amens: <entryFree id="n2209" type="main" key="a_mens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-mens</orth>, <itype>mentis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <sense id="n2209.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">out of one's senses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beside one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">senseless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">insane</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frantic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distracted</hi> (of every kind of passionate excitement; while <hi rend="ital">insanus</hi> designates one diseased in mind; and <hi rend="ital">excors</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vecors</hi>, one that is without mind; <cit><quote lang="la">among the poets a favorite word with Verg. and Ov.): inceptio est amentium, haud amantium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo amentissimus atque in omnibus consiliis praeceps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o vecors et amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arma amens capio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:314" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 314</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in dies amentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:65" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ne trepides caeli divisis partibus amens,</quote> <trans><tr>that thou tremble not senselessly at the divided heavens</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lugubris et amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:334" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 334</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cursuque amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:321" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 321</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adspectu amens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 279</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 776</bibl>; and with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amens animi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 203</bibl></cit> (cf. Rudd. II. p. 73): <cit><quote lang="la">dolore amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:3:92" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 3, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrore amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amens invidiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amens metu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculi magnitudine amens et attonitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2209.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">foolish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stupid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo audacissimus atque amentissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 3, 7</bibl></cit> (cf. a little before: <cit><quote lang="la">quod cum incredibili ejus audaciā singularis stultitia conjuncta est).—Of things: amentissimum consilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogor amenti caeca furore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impetus amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:279 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 279 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> not used.</sense></entryFree>
amentatus: <entryFree id="n2210" type="main" key="a_menta_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmentātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of amento.</entryFree>
amentia: <entryFree id="n2211" type="main" key="a_menti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmentĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>amens</etym>, <sense id="n2211.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the being out of one's senses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beside one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">madness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">insanity.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2211.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi adfectionem lumine mentis carentem nominaverunt amentiam eandemque dementiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:5:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: Di monerint meliora atque amentiam averruncassint tuam, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=102" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 102</bibl> Müll., and in Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=373" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 373</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 90 Rib.): heu cor ira fervit caecum, amentiā rapior ferorque, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 503, 7</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 194 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">Quor meam senectutem hujus sollicito amentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quae istast pravitas, Quaeve amentiast ...?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 50</bibl> (not elsewhere in Ter.): <cit><quote lang="la">flagrare cupiditate atque amentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amentiā atque audaciā praeditus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 42</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:511" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 511</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tanta vis amentiae verius quam amoris mentem turbaverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:9" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Percutiat te Dominus amentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:28:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 28, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,046:12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Zach. 12, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2211.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2211.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Folly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stupidity</hi> (cf. amens, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">si quem amentia verset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:249" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 249</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2211.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Malice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">malignity</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">propter multitudinem amentiae (tuae),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,036:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Os. 9, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amento: <entryFree id="n2212" type="main" key="a_mento"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmento</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>amentum</etym>. <sense id="n2212.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to furnish with a strap</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thong;</hi> esp. of the javelin, to the middle of which a strap was fastened, so that it might be thrown with greater force (very rare; <cit><quote lang="la">only twice in Cic.): hastae amentatae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:78:271" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 78, 271</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of discourse: <cit><quote lang="la">amentatae hastae (i. e. apta et parata argumenta),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:57:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 57, 242</bibl></cit> (so Juv. sagittae and jaculator, q. v.).—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2212.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to hurl</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dart the javelin</hi> by means of a thong: cum jaculum parvā Libysamentavit habenā, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:221" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 221</bibl>.—And of the wind, which gives an impetus to motion, as a thong to the dart: <cit><quote lang="la">amentante Noto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:422" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 422</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amentum: <entryFree id="n2213" type="main" key="a_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a(/mma, a(/ptw</foreign>; v. apo</etym>, <sense id="n2213.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a strap</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thong</hi>, esp. upon missile weapons, by means of which they were thrown with greater force (cf. amento): amenta, quibus, ut mitti possint, vinciuntur jacula sive solearum lora, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 12</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">epistola ad amentum deligata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 48</bibl></cit> Herz.: <cit><quote lang="la">inserit amento digitos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:321" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 321</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amenta torquent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:665" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 665</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umor jaculorum amenta emollierat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:41 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 41 al.</bibl></cit>—Rarely, <hi rend="ital">a shoe-string</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">soleae sine amento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 6, 14, § 31</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ameria: <entryFree id="n2214" type="main" key="A^me^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ameri/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2214.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very ancient town in Umbria</hi> (acc. to Cato, built <pb n="105" /> <cb n="AMIC" /> before the Trojan war), now <hi rend="ital">Amelia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 114</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:7 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 7 al.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕrīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Ameria</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">municeps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corbulae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">salix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 9, 37, § 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:265" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 265</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:30 al" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 30 al.</bibl>— <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕrīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ameria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 113</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĕrīna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. mala or pira), <hi rend="ital">Amerian fruit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:16:18" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 16, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
